newsitem.title: GAMBIA: Civilian challenger powers ahead in Gambia poll.
newsitem.headline: Civilian challenger powers ahead in Gambia poll.

text.p: The strongest civilian challenger to Gambia's military leader Yahya Jammeh powered ahead on Friday after three constituencies were declared in the West African country's presidential election.

Latest official results announced live on television just after midnight showed chief opposition leader Ousainou Darboe had polled a total of 4,293 ballots, against Jammeh's 3,995. Darboe outpolled Jammeh by 1,183 ballots in one constituency alone -- Keang East in the interior.

The results appear in line with predictions of a close race between Darboe, a popular Banjul lawyer who is leader of the United Democratic Party, and Jammeh, who overthrew an elected government in a 1994 coup.

Darboe's performance would also reinforce fears of how the military will react if Jammeh loses. Experts say flaws in a constitution promoted by Jammeh and adopted in a referendum last month could delay a handover of power if the opposition wins, creating conditions for unrest.
The new constitution does not come into force until it is approved by parliament, which will not be in place before December after general elections.

Jammeh's AFPRC ruling council remains in power until the new constitution comes into force -- which will not happen before parliament is elected -- and there is no legal provision as to when the elected president is sworn in.

"If Jammeh wins then there is no problem as he will just continue in office," said a legal expert in Banjul. "But there could be a problem if Darboe wins and expects to be sworn in tomorrow. His supporters may not understand this."
The Commonwealth and the United Nations described the electoral law and constitutional arrangements as flawed and called off plans to send observers for the poll.
"The transition is so awkwardly designed that it leaves complete control in the hands of the AFPRC," a Western diplomat said, adding: "This is a recipe for a particularly unstable situation."

Jammeh, candidate of the Alliance for Patriotic Reorientation and Construction, had taken an early lead after the first result was declared from Janjanbureh, the smallest constituency. There are a total of 45 constituencies in the country of one million people.
Two other civilian candidates appeared to be doing better with each new result but still remained largely marginal to the race, predicted as essentially between Jammeh and Darboe.
They are hotel manager Amath Bah of the National Reconciliation Party (NRP) and Sidia Jatta of the small People's Democratic Organisation for Independence and Socialism.
Final results are expected late on Friday.
